planets.name: Mercury
planets.description: The smallest planet in our solar system and closest to the Sun, Mercury is a world of extremes with a heavily cratered surface.
facts: Mercury has the shortest orbital period of any planet, completing a full orbit in just 88 Earth days
Surface temperatures range from -290°F (-180°C) at night to 800°F (430°C) during the day
Despite being closest to the Sun, Mercury is not the hottest planet (that's Venus)
Mercury has no atmosphere to retain heat, causing extreme temperature variations
A day on Mercury (sunrise to sunrise) lasts 176 Earth days

planets.name: Venus
planets.description: Often called Earth's twin due to similar size, Venus is the hottest planet with a toxic atmosphere of thick sulfuric acid clouds.
facts: Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system with surface temperatures around 900°F (475°C)
Venus rotates backwards (retrograde rotation) compared to most other planets
A day on Venus is longer than its year - it takes 243 Earth days to rotate once
The atmospheric pressure on Venus is 92 times that of Earth's
Venus is the brightest natural object in the night sky after the Moon

planets.name: Earth
planets.description: Our home planet, the only known world in the universe to harbor life, covered by 71% water and featuring a protective atmosphere.
facts: Earth is the only known planet with liquid water on its surface
The Earth's core is as hot as the surface of the Sun (around 10,800°F or 6,000°C)
Earth's atmosphere is composed of 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen, and 1% other gases
Our planet is about 4.5 billion years old
The Moon is slowly moving away from Earth at a rate of about 1.5 inches (3.8 cm) per year

planets.name: Mars
planets.description: The Red Planet, known for its rusty color from iron oxide, features the largest volcano and canyon in the solar system.
facts: Mars has the largest volcano in the solar system - Olympus Mons, which is about 13.6 miles (22 km) high
The Valles Marineris canyon system is 2,500 miles (4,000 km) long and up to 4 miles (7 km) deep
Mars has two small moons: Phobos and Deimos, which may be captured asteroids
Evidence suggests Mars once had liquid water on its surface
A day on Mars is very similar to Earth, lasting 24 hours and 37 minutes

planets.name: Jupiter
planets.description: The largest planet in our solar system, a gas giant with a massive storm called the Great Red Spot that has raged for hundreds of years.
facts: Jupiter is so large that all the other planets in the solar system could fit inside it
The Great Red Spot is a storm larger than Earth that has been raging for at least 400 years
Jupiter has 95 known moons, including the four large Galilean moons: Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto
Jupiter's strong magnetic field is 20,000 times stronger than Earth's
Jupiter rotates the fastest of all planets, completing one rotation in just under 10 hours

planets.name: Saturn
planets.description: The ringed planet, famous for its spectacular ring system made of billions of ice and rock particles, is the least dense planet.
facts: Saturn's rings span up to 175,000 miles (282,000 km) but are only about 30 feet (10 meters) thick
Saturn is the least dense planet - it would float in water if you could find a bathtub big enough
Saturn has 146 known moons, with Titan being the largest and having a thick atmosphere
The rings are made up of billions of particles ranging from tiny grains to house-sized chunks
Saturn's hexagonal storm at its north pole is wider than Earth

planets.name: Uranus
planets.description: The ice giant that rotates on its side, Uranus has a blue-green color from methane in its atmosphere and experiences extreme seasons.
facts: Uranus rotates nearly on its side, with an axial tilt of 97.77 degrees
The planet's blue-green color comes from methane gas in its atmosphere
Uranus has 27 known moons, all named after characters from Shakespeare and Alexander Pope
A year on Uranus equals 84 Earth years, with each pole experiencing 42 years of sunlight and 42 years of darkness
Uranus is the coldest planet with temperatures dropping to -371°F (-224°C)

planets.name: Neptune
planets.description: The windiest planet in our solar system, Neptune is a deep blue ice giant with supersonic winds and mysterious dark storms.
facts: Neptune has the strongest winds in the solar system, reaching speeds of 1,200 mph (2,000 km/h)
The planet's deep blue color is caused by methane in its atmosphere absorbing red light
Neptune has 16 known moons, with Triton being the largest and orbiting backwards
Neptune was the first planet located through mathematical predictions rather than observation
A year on Neptune equals 165 Earth years, meaning it has completed only one orbit since its discovery in 1846
